awd_titl_txt: Distributed Quantum Computing and Metrology with Alkaline Earth Atom Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
The nascent field of quantum technology is poised to profoundly affect many aspects of life by drastically improving computing power, sensor resolution, and timing accuracy while offering a new approach to cryptography that leverages the laws of quantum mechanics. Quantum entanglement – by which quantum particles cannot be described individually even when separated over great distances – is the central resource in quantum information science. While increasing the scale of locally entangled systems remains an outstanding challenge, an attractive alternative is to use non-local means of entanglement generation such as optical photons to “connect” locally entangled systems together. The goal of this project is to advance the size and utility of large-scale quantum systems through entanglement generation between remote arrays of individually controlled atoms. This program will train new generations of diverse scientists and engineers in disruptive quantum technology that is commercially viable and will advance the leadership and economic development in quantum science in the United States.

This research program will address the challenge of realizing many-body entangled states at a scale beyond classical tractability.  The system proposed will consist of arrays of alkaline-earth(-like) ytterbium atoms in optical tweezers.  Record-size distributed Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger states – with application to quantum computation and metrology – between two separated atomic array sub-systems each containing ~20-30 qubits will be demonstrated. Entangling operations within each sub-system will be performed via highly excited Rydberg states. Additionally, logically encoded qubits containing several physical qubits will be developed. Based on this architecture, gate teleportation between logically encoded qubits will be pursued as a route toward fault-tolerance. This research will merge the toolbox of precision optical metrology with those of quantum computation and communication and will enable the use of programmable many-body entanglement for quantum-enhanced metrology and distributed quantum computing and networking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During this award, we produced an array of Yb-171 atoms in optical tweezers at the magic wavelength for the optical clock transition. The atoms are cooled to a temperature of ~5 uK, and we can detect them with fidelity and survival above 0.99. Moreover, we demonstrated the ability to perform state-resolved non-destructive readout of the ground nuclear spin qubit that preserves the qubit state with probability above 0.99. This type of readout is often called "quantum nondemolition" (QND), and it is extremely helpful for many quantum science applications. Additionally, we combine this QND readout with rotations of the nuclear spin qubit to perform real-time control and feedforward to deterministically prepare the qubit after readout, often called "active qubit reset". This work resulted in a recent publication in PRX Quantum.

Since then, we have demonstrated high-fidelity atom-photon entanglement in the telecommunication wavelength band as a major step towards quantum networking and distributed quantum computing with neutral atom arrays. Moreover, we have demonstrated techniques for parallelized remote entanglement generation by coupling an array of atoms to an array of lensed optical fibers. This technique could boost the rate of remote entanglement by a factor of N between two arrays of N atoms. We show that the photon collection efficiency and the atom-photon entanglement fidelity are roughly uniform across the atom/fiber array, and that there is negligible cross talk between channels.

These results were enabled by many technical developments. First, we have demonstrated fast, high-fidelity control of the optical clock transition. This control leveraged our high-frequency laser noise cancellation technique based on fast feedforward (PRApplied paper and patent). Next, we demonstrated fast, high-fidelity control of the metastable nuclear spin qubit via single-beam stimulated Raman coupling operating at a “magic polarization angle”, as predicted in an earlier paper from this grant period (Chen et al., PRA 2022). Along the way, these two ingredients serve as the basis for “mid-circuit” measurements. Quantum information encoded in the metastable nuclear spin is not affected by probe and cooling light associated with an optical transition from the ground state. Hence, by using the optical clock transition to selectively move sub-sets of our qubits between the ground and metastable manifolds, we can choose which qubits participate in readout and cooling and which remain “shelved” in the metastable state.

The third ingredient we demonstrated is fast and high-fidelity control of the telecom band transition that is coupled to the metastable clock state. The upper state in this transition (3D1) has a lifetime of 330 ns and a wavelength of 1389 nm. It serves as the basis for the atom-photon entanglement that we have demonstrated, and thus the goal is to collect spontaneously emitted photons from the atoms. As such, we drive a pi-pulse on the telecom transition in ~15 ns using a fast acousto-optic modulator. We detect the spontaneously emitted photons with a superconducting nanowire single photon detector (SNSPD). The atom-photon entanglement is encoding via time bin photonic qubits, and tomography of the photons are performed with a time-delay Mach-Zehnder Interferometer.

Beyond these experimental activities, we have performed several theoretical studies. Most recently, we have proposed and analyzed (Jia et al., npj Quantum Information 2024) a two-qubit, “ququart” encoding within ytterbium-171 atoms based on the electronic clock transition and the nuclear spin-1/2 degree of freedom. This encoding improves resource efficiency compared to single-qubit encodings, and it enables efficient simulation of topological spin chains with shallow circuits. Additionally, we have studied collective radiance effects in a collaboration with Ana Asenjo-Garcia at Columbia University (Masson et al., PRX Quantum 2024). These studies leverage the telecom transitions of ytterbium and the ability to put ytterbium atoms in a short-spacing optical lattice. Finally, we wrote a perspective article about quantum networking with neutral atom arrays (Covey et al., npj Quantum Information 2023).

In terms of broader impacts, the PI created a middle school outreach program at Franklin STEAM Academy middle school, Champaign, IL focused on quantum technology in a three-year outreach program designed to boost qSTEM awareness in youth. Additionally, the PI participated in the Illinois Grainger College of Engineering summer “young scholars” program, which is a summer outreach program for high school students in urban Chicago. Further, the PI has taught two undergraduate courses on quantum physics that benefit from the research performed in this program. The second course – an undergraduate course on quantum computing – was created during this grant period.
